parameters.description: An MQTT topic that this thing will subscribe to, to receive the state. This can be left empty, the channel will be state-less command-only channel.
parameters.label: MQTT state topic
parameters.name: stateTopic

parameters.description: An MQTT topic that this thing will send a command to. If not set, this will be a read-only switch.
parameters.label: MQTT command topic
parameters.name: commandTopic

parameters.description: Applies transformations to an incoming MQTT topic value. A transformation example for a received JSON would be "JSONPATH:$.device.status.temperature" for a json {device: {status: { temperature: 23.2 }}}. You can chain transformations by separating them with the intersection character ∩.
parameters.label: Incoming value transformations
parameters.name: transformationPattern

parameters.description: Applies a transformation before publishing a MQTT topic value. Transformations are specialised in extracting a value, but some transformations like the MAP one could be useful.
parameters.label: Outgoing value transformation
parameters.name: transformationPatternOut

parameters.description: Format a value before it is published to the MQTT broker. The default is to just pass the channel/item state. If you want to apply a prefix, say "MYCOLOR,", you would use "MYCOLOR,%s". If you want to adjust the precision of a number to for example 4 digits, you would use "%.4f".
parameters.label: Outgoing value format
parameters.name: formatBeforePublish

parameters.description: The value will be published to the command topic as retained message. A retained value stays on the broker and can even be seen by MQTT clients that are subscribing at a later point in time.
parameters.label: Retained
parameters.name: retained

parameters.description: If the received MQTT value should not only update the state of linked items, but command them, enable this option.
parameters.label: Is command
parameters.name: postCommand

parameters.description: A number (like 1, 10) or a string (like "enabled") that is recognised as on/open state. You can use this parameter for a second keyword, next to ON (OPEN respectively on a Contact).
parameters.label: On/Open value
parameters.name: on

parameters.description: A number (like 0, -10) or a string (like "disabled") that is recognised as off/closed state. You can use this parameter for a second keyword, next to OFF (CLOSED respectively on a Contact).
parameters.label: Off/Closed value
parameters.name: off

parameters.description: If you connect this channel to a Switch item and turn it on, color and saturation are preserved from the last state, but the brightness will be set to this configured initial brightness percentage.
parameters.label: Initial brightness
parameters.name: onBrightness

parameters.description: This channel will trigger on this MQTT topic. This topic can contain wildcards like + and # for example "all/in/#" or "sensors/+/config".
parameters.label: MQTT Topic
parameters.name: stateTopic

parameters.description: An optional condition on the value of the MQTT topic that must match before this channel is triggered.
parameters.label: Payload condition
parameters.name: payload

parameters.description: The trigger channel payload usually only contains the received MQTT topic value. If you define a separator character, for example '#', the topic and received value will be in the trigger channel payload. For example: my_topic#my_received_value.
parameters.label: Separator character
parameters.name: separator

channel-types.description: This channel is triggered when a value is published to the configured MQTT topic on this broker connection. The event payload will be the received MQTT topic value.

parameters.description: Applies transformations to an incoming MQTT topic value. A transformation example for a received JSON would be "JSONPATH:$.device.status.temperature" for a json {device: {status: { temperature: 23.2 }}}. You can chain transformations by separating them with the intersection character ∩.
parameters.label: Incoming value transformations
parameters.name: transformationPattern

parameters.description: Applies a transformation before publishing a MQTT topic value. Transformations are specialised in extracting a value, but some transformations like the MAP one could be useful.
parameters.label: Outgoing value transformation
parameters.name: transformationPatternOut

parameters.description:
Format a value before it is published to the MQTT broker. The default is to just pass the channel/item state. If you want to apply a prefix, say "MYCOLOR,
", you would use "MYCOLOR,%s". If you want to adjust the precision of a number to for example 4 digits, you would use "%.4f".
parameters.label: Outgoing value format
parameters.name: formatBeforePublish

parameters.description: The value will be published to the command topic as retained message. A retained value stays on the broker and can even be seen by MQTT clients that are subscribing at a later point in time.
parameters.label: Retained
parameters.name: retained

parameters.description: If the received MQTT value should not only update the state of linked items, but command them, enable this option.
parameters.label: Is command
parameters.name: postCommand

parameters.description: If your MQTT topic is limited to a set of one or more specific commands or specific states, define those states here. Separate multiple states with commas. An example for a light bulb state set: ON,DIMMED,OFF
parameters.label: Allowed states
parameters.name: allowedStates

parameters.description: Allows or disallows to use system pings next to the java integrated ping functionality. On windows the system ping works more reliable most of the time.

parameters.description: Usually a device requests an IP address in an IPv4 network with the help of DHCP as soon as it enters a network. If we listen to those packets, we can detect a device presence even faster. You need elevated access rights (see readme) for this to work.

parameters.description: The result of a device presence detection is cached for a small amount of time. Be aware that no new pings will be issued within this time frame, even if explicitly requested.

parameters.description: Pairing must be enabled to connect a new device. Pairing is automatically disabled after the configured pairing time (usually 60 seconds).

parameters.description: The Amazon echos have no means to recreate a new api key and they don't care about the 403-forbidden http status code. If the addon has pruned its known users (reinstall etc), echos will not be able to discover new devices. Set this option to just create new users on the fly on the next pairing mode period.
parameters.label: Amazon Echo device discovery fix

parameters.description: The HUE emulation can either publish Switch items if this is set to an empty string or filter items by tags. You can supply multiple tags by separating them with a comma.

parameters.description:

Example: "Latn" (Latin), "Cyrl" (Cyrillic)

Example: "US" (United States), "DE" (Germany), "FR" (France), "029" (Caribbean)

parameters.name: certificatepin

parameters.description: If **certificatepin** is set this hash is used to verify the connection. Clear to allow a new certificate pinning on the next connection attempt. If empty will be filled automatically by the next successful connection. An example input would be `SHA-256: 83F9171E06A313118889F7D79302BD1B7A2042EE0CFD029ABF8DD06FFA6CD9D3`.

parameters.name: certificate

parameters.description: If this and SSL is set: After the next connection has been successfully established, the public key of the broker is pinned. parameters.label: Public key pinning
parameters.name: publickeypin

parameters.description: If **publickeypin** is set this hash is used to verify the connection. Clear to allow a new public key pinning on the next connection attempt. parameterGroups.description: These configuration parameters allow you to alter a value before it is published to MQTT or before a received value is assigned to an item.

parameters.description: HomeAssistant Object ID
parameters.label: Object ID
parameters.name: objectid

parameters.description: MQTT base prefix
parameters.label: MQTT base prefix
parameters.name: basetopic

parameters.description: Homie Device ID. This is part of the MQTT topic, e.g. "homie/deviceid/$homie".
parameters.label: Device ID
parameters.name: deviceid

parameters.description: MQTT base prefix
parameters.label: MQTT base prefix
parameters.name: basetopic

parameters.description: An MQTT topic that this thing will subscribe to, to receive the state. This can be left empty, the channel will be state-less command-only channel.
parameters.label: MQTT state topic
parameters.name: stateTopic

parameters.description: An MQTT topic that this thing will send a command to. If not set, this will be a read-only switch.
parameters.label: MQTT command topic
parameters.name: commandTopic

parameters.description: Applies transformations to an incoming MQTT topic value. A transformation example for a received JSON would be "JSONPATH:$.device.status.temperature" for a json {device: {status: { temperature: 23.2 }}}. You can chain transformations by separating them with the intersection character ∩.
parameters.label: Incoming value transformations
parameters.name: transformationPattern

parameters.description: Applies a transformation before publishing a MQTT topic value. Transformations are specialised in extracting a value, but some transformations like the MAP one could be useful.
parameters.label: Outgoing value transformation
parameters.name: transformationPatternOut

parameters.description:
Format a value before it is published to the MQTT broker. The default is to just pass the channel/item state. If you 
want to apply a prefix, say "MYCOLOR,", you would use "MYCOLOR,%s". If you want to adjust the precision of a number to for example 4 digits, you would use "%.4f".
parameters.label: Outgoing value format
parameters.name: formatBeforePublish

parameters.description: The value will be published to the command topic as retained message. A retained value stays on the broker and can even be seen by MQTT clients that are subscribing at a later point in time.
parameters.label: Retained
parameters.name: retained

persistence-services.description: This service allows you to persist state updates using the Amazon DynamoDB database.
persistence-services.label: Amazon DynamoDB Persistence

persistence-services.description: This service allows you to persist and query states using the InfluxDB time series database.
persistence-services.label: InfluxDB

persistence-services.description: This service allows you to persist state updates using a SQL or NoSQL database through the Java Persistence API
persistence-services.label: Java Persistence API

persistence-services.description: The mapdb Persistence Service is based on simple key-value store that only saves the last value. The intention is to use this for restoreOnStartup items because all other persistence options have their drawbacks if values are only needed for reload.
persistence-services.label: mapdb

persistence-services.description: rrd4j is a round-robin database and does not grow in size - it has a fixed allocated size, which is used. This is accomplished by doing data compression, which means that the older the data is, the less values are available. So while you might have a value every minute for the last 24 hours, you might only have one every day for the last year.
persistence-services.label: rrd4j

persistence.annotation: Allows an overview of when my items updated to a new value
persistence.label: InfluxDB History

persistence.annotation: Restores all my items on startup
persistence.label: MapDB Restore

persistence.annotation: Stores all items to mapDB for a later restart
persistence.label: MapDB Restore

configParameters.description: The IP/Hostname of the MQTT broker
configParameters.label: Broker Hostname/IP
configParameters.name: host

configParameters.description: The port is optional, if none is provided, the typical ports 1883 and 8883 (SSL) are used.
configParameters.label: Broker Port
configParameters.name: port

configParameters.description: Uses TLS/SSL to establish a secure connection to the broker.
configParameters.label: Secure connection
configParameters.name: secure

configParameters.description: Use a fixed client ID. Defaults to empty which means a client ID is generated for this connection.
configParameters.label: Client ID
configParameters.name: clientID

configParameters.description: Retained messages are stored on the MQTT broker and other clients can retrieve the value at any time
configParameters.label: Retain messages
configParameters.name: retain

configParameters.description: Reconnect time in ms. If a connection is lost, the binding will wait this time before it tries to reconnect.
configParameters.label: Reconnect time
configParameters.name: reconnect_time

configParameters.description: Keep alive / heartbeat timer in ms. It can take up to this time to determine if a server connection is lost. A lower value may keep the broker unnecessarily busy for no or little additional value.
configParameters.label: Heartbeat
configParameters.name: keep_alive_time

configParameters.description: The last will message.
configParameters.label: Last will message
configParameters.name: lastwill_message

configParameters.description: Defaults to empty and therefore disables the last will.
configParameters.label: Last will topic
configParameters.name: lastwill_topic

configParameters.description: The quality of service parameter of the last will.
configParameters.label: Last will QoS
configParameters.name: lastwill_qos

configParameters.description: The MQTT username
configParameters.label: Username
configParameters.name: username

configParameters.description: The MQTT password
configParameters.label: Password
configParameters.name: password

configParameters.description: If this and SSL is set: After the next connection has been successfully established, the certificate is pinned. The connection will be refused if another certificate is used. Clear **certificate** to allow a new certificate for the next connection attempt. This option can increase security.
configParameters.label: Certificate pinning
configParameters.name: certificatepin

configParameters.description: If **certificatepin** is set this hash is used to verify the connection. Clear to allow a new certificate pinning on the next connection attempt. If empty will be filled automatically by the next successful connection. An example input would be `SHA-256:83F9171E06A313118889F7D79302BD1B7A2042EE0CFD029ABF8DD06FFA6CD9D3`.
configParameters.label: Certificate hash
configParameters.name: certificate

configParameters.description: If this and SSL is set: After the next connection has been successfully established, the public key of the broker is pinned. The connection will be refused if another public key is used. Clear **publickey** to allow a new public key for the next connection attempt. This option can increase security.
configParameters.label: Public key pinning
configParameters.name: publickeypin

configParameters.description: If **publickeypin** is set this hash is used to verify the connection. Clear to allow a new public key pinning on the next connection attempt. If empty will be filled automatically by the next successful connection. An example input would be `SHA-256:83F9171E06A313118889F7D79302BD1B7A2042EE0CFD029ABF8DD06FFA6CD9D3`
configParameters.label: Public Key Hash
configParameters.name: publickey
